column2: VILLARS TO EVELINA.
column3: VILLARS TO EVELINA.

column2: Berry Hill, Sept. 28th.
column3: Berry Hill, september twenty eighth.

column2: DEAD to the world, and equally insensible to its pleasures or its pains, I long since bad adieu to all joy, and defiance to all sorrow, but what should spring from my Evelina,-sole source, to me, of all earthly felicity.
column3: DEAD to the world, and equally insensible to its pleasures or its pains, I long since bad adieu to all joy, and defiance to all sorrow, but what should spring from my Evelina,-sole source, to me, of all earthly felicity.

column2: Alas, my child!-that innocence, the first, best gift of Heaven, should, of all others, be the blindest to its own danger,-the most exposed to treachery,-and the least able to defend itself, in a world where it is little known, less valued, and perpetually deceived!
column3: Alas, my child!-that innocence, the first, best gift of Heaven, should, of all others, be the blindest to its own danger,-the most exposed to treachery,-and the least able to defend itself, in a world where it is little known, less valued, and perpetually deceived!

column2: Would to Heaven you were here!-then, by degrees, and with gentleness, I might enter upon a subject too delicate for distant discussion.
column3: Would to Heaven you were here!-then, by degrees, and with gentleness, I might enter upon a subject too delicate for distant discussion.

column2: Hitherto I have forborne to speak with you upon the most important of all concerns, the state of your heart:-alas, I need no information!
column3: Hitherto I have forborne to speak with you upon the most important of all concerns, the state of your heart:-alas, I need no information!

column2: I have been silent, indeed, but I have not been blind.
column3: I have been silent, indeed, but I have not been blind.

column2: Long, and with the deepest regret, have I perceived the ascendancy which Lord Orville has gained upon your mind.-You will start at the mention of his name,-you will tremble every word you read;-I grieve to give pain to my gentle Evelina, but I dare not any longer spare her.
column3: Long, and with the deepest regret, have I perceived the ascendancy which Lord Orville has gained upon your mind.-You will start at the mention of his name,-you will tremble every word you read;-I grieve to give pain to my gentle Evelina, but I dare not any longer spare her.

column2: Your first meeting with Lord Orville was decisive.
column3: Your first meeting with Lord Orville was decisive.

column2: Young, animated, entirely off your guard, and thoughtless of consequences, Imagination took the reins; and Reason, slow-paced, though sure-footed, was unequal to the race of so eccentric and flighty a companion.
column3: Young, animated, entirely off your guard, and thoughtless of consequences, Imagination took the reins; and Reason, slow paced, though sure footed, was unequal to the race of so eccentric and flighty a companion.

column2: How rapid was then my Evelina's progress through those regions of fancy and passion whither her new guide conducted her!-She saw Lord Orville at a ball,-and he was the most amiable of men!
column3: How rapid was then my Evelina's progress through those regions of fancy and passion whither her new guide conducted her!-She saw Lord Orville at a ball,-and he was the most amiable of men!

column2: -She met him again at another,-and he had every virtue under Heaven!
column3: -She met him again at another,-and he had every virtue under Heaven!

column2: You flattered yourself that your partiality was the effect of esteem, founded upon a general love of merit, and a principle of justice; and your heart, which fell the sacrifice of your error, was totally gone ere you expected it was in danger.
column3: You flattered yourself that your partiality was the effect of esteem, founded upon a general love of merit, and a principle of justice; and your heart, which fell the sacrifice of your error, was totally gone ere you expected it was in danger.

column2: But, now, since you have again met, and have become more intimate than ever, all my hope from silence and seeming ignorance is at an end.
column3: But, now, since you have again met, and have become more intimate than ever, all my hope from silence and seeming ignorance is at an end.

column2: Make a noble effort for the recovery of your peace, which now, with sorrow I see it, depends wholly upon the presence of Lord Orville.
column3: Make a noble effort for the recovery of your peace, which now, with sorrow I see it, depends wholly upon the presence of Lord Orville.

column2: This effort may indeed be painful; but trust to my experience, when I assure you it is requisite.
column3: This effort may indeed be painful; but trust to my experience, when I assure you it is requisite.

column2: You must quit him!-his sight is baneful to your repose, his society is death to your future tranquillity!
column3: You must quit him!-his sight is baneful to your repose, his society is death to your future tranquillity!

column2: Believe me, my beloved child, my heart aches for your suffering, while it dictates its necessity.
column3: Believe me, my beloved child, my heart aches for your suffering, while it dictates its necessity.

column2: Your health, you tell me, is much mended:-Can you then consent to leave Bristol?-not abruptly, that I do not desire, but in a few days from the time you receive this?
column3: Your health, you tell me, is much mended:-Can you then consent to leave Bristol?-not abruptly, that I do not desire, but in a few days from the time you receive this?

column2: I will write to Mrs. Selwyn, and tell her how much I wish your return; and Mrs. Clinton can take sufficient care of you.
column3: I will write to mrs Selwyn, and tell her how much I wish your return; and mrs Clinton can take sufficient care of you.

column2: I have meditated upon every possible expedient that might tend to your happiness, ere I fixed upon exacting from you a compliance which I am convinced will be most painful to you; but I can satisfy myself in none.
column3: I have meditated upon every possible expedient that might tend to your happiness, ere I fixed upon exacting from you a compliance which I am convinced will be most painful to you; but I can satisfy myself in none.

column2: This will at least be safe; and as to success,-we must leave it to time.
column3: This will at least be safe; and as to success,-we must leave it to time.

column2: I am very glad to hear of Mr. Macartney's welfare.
column3: I am very glad to hear of mr Macartney's welfare.

column2: Heaven preserve and strengthen you!
column3: Heaven preserve and strengthen you!
